title: Kaffeine brings a jolt of world coffee tradition to Mass Ave
text:
Kaffeine brings a jolt of world coffee tradition to Mass Ave Gwen Ragno, IndyStar correspondent 11:16 a.m. ET Feb. 10, 2017 Buy Photo Chis Kilander makes clasic Vietnamese coffee that he will lighten with sweetened condensed milk at Kaffeine Coffee Co. He co-owns the coffee business with his wife Amanda Kilander. (Photo: Kelly Wilkinson/IndyStar) Buy Photo 160 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
When the Kaffeine Coffee truck started roaming the streets of Indianapolis eight years ago, people weren't as open to learning about coffee. 
In a world of pumpkin spice lattes and caramel macchiatos, it could be challenging to be one of the few not adding syrups to their drinks, said co-owner Amanda Kilander. 
She and her husband, Chris Kilander, have always taken pride in their focus on third-wave coffee — a style popular in cities like Seattle and Portland, Ore., but rare in Indianapolis. 
“We really had to stand our ground in saying we truly believe this is the way we want to do coffee,” she said. 
Now, Kaffeine is one of the hottest coffee shops in town. It opened in mid-September in the Mass Ave. district at 707 Fulton St., in a garage-style space behind Circa Apartments. 
The philosophy behind third-wave coffee is that instead of adding things like syrups and flavors to the coffee, they start with top-quality beans from around the world and focus on simple brewing techniques to bring out the best flavors. Buy Photo 
A latte is made at Kaffeine Coffee Co., Thursday, October 27, 2016. (Photo: Kelly Wilkinson/IndyStar) 
With 22 years of experience in the coffee business, Chris Kilander said he believes it all comes down to “a simple product, simple technique, simple results.” 
The world map presiding over the coffee bar at the center of the Kaffeine Coffee speaks to the Kilanders’ mission of placing an emphasis on the origins of the coffees they serve. The map shows the coffee belt — which stretches between the tropics of Capricorn and Cancer — and regions that are color-coded with the bags of coffee beans that originate there. Eventually, Kilander said, he wants to add LED lights that will illuminate a coffee’s country of origin while it’s brewing. 
Single-origin coffees are becoming more common on the Indy coffee scene, but the Kilanders take it a few steps further. Certain specialty drinks on the menu use the brewing techniques, recipes and serving sizes traditional to the coffee’s country or region of origin. 
The Vietnamese coffee, for instance, uses beans from Vietnam brewed in a phin brewer, served over ice with sweetened condensed milk. 
Another popular choice is the bicerin coffee, a drink native to Turin, Italy, that layers Italian espresso over dark chocolate, topped with layers of steamed milk and foam. 
Even the chai — available in black, green and red blends — is made in-house from real spices just like it is made in India. 
Kilander said he’s excited about the opportunities the Mass Ave.-area space will give him to explore new innovations in coffee — from a healthier decaf to a new way of making cold brew. Rather than mimicking the trends of the moment, he plans to continue doing his own thing. 
“People want to come to a unique experience,” he said. “If someone comes to Indianapolis, you don’t want to go to a typical coffee shop, you want something that when you leave you go, ‘Wow, I remember that coffee we had in Indianapolis.’” 160 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://indy.st/2kX82wi TOP VIDEOS
